title: Team Leader

advice: Better training; restructure; listen to floor staff
cons: Extremely inconsistent breaks between employees (deliberate due to hour structuring)
pros: Reasonable benfits (salary, leisure reimbursement for gigs, arts etc.)
text: Pros Reasonable benfits (salary, leisure reimbursement for gigs, arts etc.) Good intranet Cheap food available on breaks Salary consistent across age groups Cons Extremely inconsistent breaks between employees (deliberate due to hour structuring) Poor branch management Training almost non existent (relying on other staff to ad-hoc teach you) Difficulty booking holidays at times Inability to appropriately schedule overtime - regularly asked to 'add hours' at end of shifts rather than simply sign up to shifts with ability to plan Upward mobility difficult without full time role & very good relationship with managers No floor staff suggestions listened to Advice to Management Better training; restructure; listen to floor staff

title: Part Time Job- Student

advice: look after the partners and they will look after customers! at the moment customer comes first, that's why partners are unwilling to work and there's high turnover. Look into the pay gap for Assistant Team Managers as they do pretty much the same thing as Section managers but the gap is atrocious. Some partners are getting paid higher than managers and you expect respect!
cons: awful conditions with new 'modern waitrose' scheme, unrealistic expectations, no support with training needs, always having to stay longer hours and as a manager you don't get paid for overtime but it is unrealistic to get the time back ever
pros: great discount both at Waitrose and John Lewis and other additional benefits such as holiday offers, discounts at partner restaurants etc.
text: Pros great discount both at Waitrose and John Lewis and other additional benefits such as holiday offers, discounts at partner restaurants etc. Cons awful conditions with new 'modern waitrose' scheme, unrealistic expectations, no support with training needs, always having to stay longer hours and as a manager you don't get paid for overtime but it is unrealistic to get the time back ever Advice to Management look after the partners and they will look after customers! at the moment customer comes first, that's why partners are unwilling to work and there's high turnover. Look into the pay gap for Assistant Team Managers as they do pretty much the same thing as Section managers but the gap is atrocious. Some partners are getting paid higher than managers and you expect respect!
title: good for a weekend job, not as a career

advice: Stop pushing the idea that everyone is a partner, when you then don't listen to our views, or do nothing about it when you do occasionally give us the time of day.
cons: A few very rude customers, who seems to expect the world from you because you work at Waitrose. This got so ridiculous I was once asked to get a certain type of bread in stock for a ladies next visit... She told me I could get it at Sainsburys. I told her to go there - this wasn't the most diplomatic solution I admit.
pros: Decent benefits & generally friendly staff members.
text: Pros Decent benefits & generally friendly staff members. Cons A few very rude customers, who seems to expect the world from you because you work at Waitrose. This got so ridiculous I was once asked to get a certain type of bread in stock for a ladies next visit... She told me I could get it at Sainsburys. I told her to go there - this wasn't the most diplomatic solution I admit. Also the management was atrocious due to inconsistency, and lack of motivation. Only once did I have a manager who wanted to be working as my manager. Advice to Management Stop pushing the idea that everyone is a partner, when you then don't listen to our views, or do nothing about it when you do occasionally give us the time of day. Hire people in management position who are going to have at least a year or two in the role - not people at university. ASM don't work if they are only around at Christmas, as they don't have a rapport with new staff, or any clue whats going on in terms of the ever-changing management.
title: Part Time Supervisor (throughout higher education)(204 Branch)

advice: Exchange for some different model or re-programme the current one.
cons: So-called 'management' that cannot cope with stress and pass it over to partners
pros: Very, I mean very understandable people, always ready to help and help you out whatever your situation is (Head Office only!)
text: Pros Very, I mean very understandable people, always ready to help and help you out whatever your situation is (Head Office only!) Year bonus (from your to year lower but it is) Cons So-called 'management' that cannot cope with stress and pass it over to partners Biased approach to some partners People with spasm on their face instead of genuine smile that makes you feel you live in a virtual world Again so-called 'management' promising pies in the sky with development ending up with no support whatsoever. Advice to Management Exchange for some different model or re-programme the current one.

Cons Limited movement upwards but more opportunity side wards as some people stay in the same job/level for years. With having structure and process they are not as agile or quick to make things happen so can be slow Advice to Management Realise talent and give opportunities, be flexible and more agile. Continue with the great culture
title: Head office roles

advice: Keep valuing the 'partners'. Allow room for creative innovation but also faster execution of that innovation.
cons: - too much analysis paralysis
pros: - co-owned model means everybody genuinely has a voice in the business
text: Pros - co-owned model means everybody genuinely has a voice in the business - focus on longer term priorities avoids short-sighted snap decision making - great on site facilities at Bracknell based HQ - respectful and friendly culture - generally good work/life balance - excellent perks and benefits incl. 25% off at John Lewis and 15% off at Waitrose - gender diverse workforce Cons - too much analysis paralysis - unnecessary layers of middle management - lack of fresh blood and ideas due to a fairly unchanging workforce - performance management lacks teeth Advice to Management Keep valuing the 'partners'. Allow room for creative innovation but also faster execution of that innovation.

advice: investigate the lack of senior management who seem to have little to no understanding of what's going on or hide it under the table
cons: Some poor senior management especially from operations point of view
pros: Great benefits, helpful colleagues, lots of overtime, flexible working times
text: Pros Great benefits, helpful colleagues, lots of overtime, flexible working times Cons Some poor senior management especially from operations point of view warehouse illogically set out Bad training (if any at all) Too many chiefs Hard to gain promotion or move higher Routes are scheduled with NO breaks! Given routes that start before shift, so inevitably late to deliveries Verbal abuse by clients for being late etc.. Expect to be given an easy route when you start, which in no way is a true reflection of the work given afterwards Some staff are given preferential treatments on their manifest, so deliver much much less A GPS system which is outdated and Waitrose has not paid for traffic alert, so expect to be directed towards lots of traffic. Old and outdated handheld that persistently crashes and makes the job even more difficult Clothing that makes you sweat so that your underclothing is wet through Expect to carry tons of water up flights of stairs in London apartments with no lift and be treated like a second class citizen Filthy internal vans with mould where the food is Dirty food crates Great benefits, if you can afford them on the very low wages Advice to Management investigate the lack of senior management who seem to have little to no understanding of what's going on or hide it under the table

title: waitrose

advice: Waitrose supposedly has a history for regarding its staff but that is not true as this place does not care about their staff at all especially new employees. Its a daunting process to start a new job especially one you are not familiar with and I believe new recruits need a helping hand, guidance and plenty of information to get them started. Not wondering around like a headless chicken trying to find someone who is too busy eating their Christmas dinner.
cons: I worked there one day and I quit the first day. Why? Firstly it took 5 weeks between interview stage and starting day. Nobody contacted me in the run up to my start date telling me what time to come in, who to ask for and what to wear. I made endless calls the day before with no luck only to talk to a line manager who did not care and said "I dont know, come in at 10am alright bye". This was supposedly my line manager. After calling the whole day that was my answer. Upon arrival of my first day I was brought up to a room and sat at a computer where I had to do my training online. I was left for 6 hours by myself to do this where nobody came back for me or to check on me. There was a lot of difficult stuff to get through with some things I did not understand and nobody around to ask. I was not given training face to face, shown around the building/staff area. I was not given a uniform or shown where to come in the following morning as it was a 7am start before the store even opened. It was a lot of stress and a lot of effort on my part to get people to try and help me even though they were the ones recruiting me that I decided to leave for the lack of efficiency and total unprofessional work ethic of the management.
pros: The interview stage was the only positive experience about this company. It was 30 minutes and the hiring manager was a very nice man.
text: Pros The interview stage was the only positive experience about this company. It was 30 minutes and the hiring manager was a very nice man. Cons I worked there one day and I quit the first day. Why? Firstly it took 5 weeks between interview stage and starting day. Nobody contacted me in the run up to my start date telling me what time to come in, who to ask for and what to wear. I made endless calls the day before with no luck only to talk to a line manager who did not care and said "I dont know, come in at 10am alright bye". This was supposedly my line manager. After calling the whole day that was my answer. Upon arrival of my first day I was brought up to a room and sat at a computer where I had to do my training online. I was left for 6 hours by myself to do this where nobody came back for me or to check on me. There was a lot of difficult stuff to get through with some things I did not understand and nobody around to ask. I was not given training face to face, shown around the building/staff area. I was not given a uniform or shown where to come in the following morning as it was a 7am start before the store even opened. It was a lot of stress and a lot of effort on my part to get people to try and help me even though they were the ones recruiting me that I decided to leave for the lack of efficiency and total unprofessional work ethic of the management. Advice to Management Waitrose supposedly has a history for regarding its staff but that is not true as this place does not care about their staff at all especially new employees. Its a daunting process to start a new job especially one you are not familiar with and I believe new recruits need a helping hand, guidance and plenty of information to get them started. Not wondering around like a headless chicken trying to find someone who is too busy eating their Christmas dinner.
title: Not what they claim to represent

cons: Poorly staffed, modern Waitrose is failing, poor wages, lack of development

title: Good

advice: Understand that younger staff do have a life outside of their part-time job.
cons: My partnership discount card didn’t come for over a month after it was meant to - a common thing you found was if Waitrose needed something from you it had to be your top priority, whilst if you needed something from them it was always brushed under the carpet. Awfully unsociable hours and the rotas would sometimes change without your knowledge. Pay rises may happen at the assessments, but even after 5 months they did not do my 3 month assessment (again, if it’s something to do with an employes interest it is not their priority). Some of the managers are not understanding in the slightest too.
pros: I think the best thing about working for this company is how close you get to all the staff so quickly. You get a great discount for Waitrose (15%) and at John Lewis (25%) after 3 months. Great training and experience, quickly become an expert on your department if you put your all in.
text: Pros I think the best thing about working for this company is how close you get to all the staff so quickly. You get a great discount for Waitrose (15%) and at John Lewis (25%) after 3 months. Great training and experience, quickly become an expert on your department if you put your all in. Cons My partnership discount card didn’t come for over a month after it was meant to - a common thing you found was if Waitrose needed something from you it had to be your top priority, whilst if you needed something from them it was always brushed under the carpet. Awfully unsociable hours and the rotas would sometimes change without your knowledge. Pay rises may happen at the assessments, but even after 5 months they did not do my 3 month assessment (again, if it’s something to do with an employes interest it is not their priority). Some of the managers are not understanding in the slightest too. Advice to Management Understand that younger staff do have a life outside of their part-time job.

advice: Praise and recognise talent before it leaves and goes somewhere else. Remove stagnant managers. The company is a good one to work for.
cons: At the management level you will be paid for a 39 hours week but will be expected to work well into the 50-60 hour mark but potentially longer if you include travel time.
pros: Strong core values that resonate throughout he whole business.
text: Pros Strong core values that resonate throughout he whole business. Cons At the management level you will be paid for a 39 hours week but will be expected to work well into the 50-60 hour mark but potentially longer if you include travel time. Good managers are exploited to work extremely hard and take on a lot of responsibility whilst bad managers coast along seemingly without reprisal. Advice to Management Praise and recognise talent before it leaves and goes somewhere else. Remove stagnant managers. The company is a good one to work for.

title: Supermarket assistant

advice: Employ more people, 30+ more per branch
cons: Being under 20 I feel that the management really push you and put too much stress on you.
pros: Good pay, discounts and benefits are good,
text: Pros Good pay, discounts and benefits are good, Good opportunity’s to get overtime Good company to work for Most customers and stores are nice Cons Being under 20 I feel that the management really push you and put too much stress on you. Also human mistakes are not well expected, I work in reductions and have occasionally missed a few on the products, this ‘mistake’ resulted in me getting disciplinary action which is ridiculous considering that it has been no more than £10 missed... Also as well a huge lack of staff in my store there is a lack of managers that actually understand how reductions, I am often running my department on a Saturday evening as the other managers haven’t got a clue what they’re doing! I am doing this on under £8 per hour and have requested a pay rise but said that I don’t have enough responsibility for it.... Advice to Management Employ more people, 30+ more per branch Get rid of modern Waitrose More trained full time staff Train managers and senior staff about mental health in young employees

title: Great part time work

advice: Review the selection process and training for Section Managers - many don't have a clue, are floundering and you can't advise them because they 'know it all' and you're just a 'supermarket assistant'. Most couldnt lead a dog let alone a team.
cons: Discount is not great considering the price of the food
pros: Its warm and dry (unless you're working in the freezer, chillers, behind meat and fish/deli counters or out in 'the yard'.
text: Pros Its warm and dry (unless you're working in the freezer, chillers, behind meat and fish/deli counters or out in 'the yard'. Food in the dining room/canteen is subsidised. Senior management are skilled but hampered by inept 'middle managers'. Cons Discount is not great considering the price of the food No union representation Poor rate of pay compared to other retail jobs (used to rely on the annual bonus to make it up - that bonus has been declining rapidly - this year chances are it will be between 0 and 3%) Pension fund is in a shambles Whole business being propped up by John Lewis sales They now expect you to do five jobs in the time given for one Section managers generally appear to have little training in leadership or management before being given an ipad, an air of authority and a total disregard for the welfare of their staff. They're implementing 'modern Waitrose' whereby you just keep getting pulled from doing a job on one section to do a job on another (whether you're trained or not) because the section managers can't plan. You then return to your original job (eventually) to find yourself getting a telling off for not having done it quickly enough (or at all). One branch rota. There isn't space for me to tell you all that's bad about that! Suffice to say, its not working. To save money they don't recruit until people leave (school age heading to Uni - happens every year at the same time and they know it does) so you end up short staffed, underpaid and overworked. Turnover is 80% plus in an industry where the average is 33% - and they wonder why? Advice to Management Review the selection process and training for Section Managers - many don't have a clue, are floundering and you can't advise them because they 'know it all' and you're just a 'supermarket assistant'. Most couldnt lead a dog let alone a team.
title: Was good, now appalling...

advice: Correct the wage when applying on the site, When I applied it said I was too get £9.21 hourly. But when I started they told me it wasn't correct it was actually £7.60 hell of a difference too what it was advising. I wouldn't of left my job if it was that low.
cons: Low wage with hard work.
pros: 15% discount after 3 months of employment.
text: Pros 15% discount after 3 months of employment. Cons Low wage with hard work. Advice to Management Correct the wage when applying on the site, When I applied it said I was too get £9.21 hourly. But when I started they told me it wasn't correct it was actually £7.60 hell of a difference too what it was advising. I wouldn't of left my job if it was that low. I worked in Eldon Square, Newcastle store. Whilst interviewing the person, you should mention too them that Waitrose has no staff parking and that the cheapest parking is eldon gardens at £120 month. I was furious at this as I wasn't getting much money too begin with.

text: Pros Decent pay for an under 18y/o, lovely colleagues and a great bonus in March due to the partnership structure of the company. Cons Holiday is a little inflexible - you have to decide at the beginning of each tax year when you want time off over the next 12 months Advice to Management Maybe be a little more flexible regarding shift-swapping as it would ease up the pressure of having to decide on holiday dates for the whole year

cons: Not a lot of opportunity to move up in the company at the mo due to the axing of many department manager jobs, meaning many are stepping down to team manager or equivalent roles and any new department manager jobs that do come up are snapped up by those who lost their old role.
pros: Treated with respect
text: Pros Treated with respect Good work/life balance for retail Good pension and benefits inc discount and subsidised tickets, etc Real sense of team spirit at work Profit sharing bonus Cons Not a lot of opportunity to move up in the company at the mo due to the axing of many department manager jobs, meaning many are stepping down to team manager or equivalent roles and any new department manager jobs that do come up are snapped up by those who lost their old role. Bonus - not been great for a few years, reflecting the food retail industry's current state of affairs.

title: Great Company

pros: First a group assessment which made you feel relaxed followed by one to one which asked you about situation you have had in your life contacted to work or outside of work, I was made to feel very comfortable and found it very easy to talk to the interviewer, there is a friendly feel from all the staff you meet which helps you from the moment you walk in.
text: Pros First a group assessment which made you feel relaxed followed by one to one which asked you about situation you have had in your life contacted to work or outside of work, I was made to feel very comfortable and found it very easy to talk to the interviewer, there is a friendly feel from all the staff you meet which helps you from the moment you walk in. Cons I did not really see anything that was wrong maybe access to water as we all got there very early and not everyone brought a water bottle I did.
title: Interview in food sales department

advice: Stop making it harder for students to work around their studies, increase flexibility with holidays and shift swapping.
cons: Inflexible working + Awkward holidays
pros: Employee Benefits + Company Culture/Values
text: Pros Employee Benefits + Company Culture/Values Cons Inflexible working + Awkward holidays Advice to Management Stop making it harder for students to work around their studies, increase flexibility with holidays and shift swapping. Recent management structure changes seem to have made career opportunities much harder to achieve too. Understandably the company needs to become more competitive and these changes have been made in spite of this, but not ideal for some staff and is pushing away a lot of the key workforce with other commitments,
title: Great company -Negative changes for <21 hour employees
